author: odyslam
content: Is following various #channels in this discord and starting chiming in on discussions about EIPS/proposed changes a good strategy? Do we have like an index of open questions that we are working towards, or the index is this discord's channels?

author: trent_vanepps
content:
following the various channels for a few days is probably not a bad idea, just be aware that some of them see less traffic tho. 

I don't think any projects in this first cohort will result in EIPs, though that's not to say it's impossible.

there are some initial topics here, but aren't necessarily open areas of research:
https://github.com/ethereum-cdap/cohort-zero/blob/main/stage-1-project-discovery.md

author: trent_vanepps
content: we have sent emails to all applicants, you should have received something

author: trent_vanepps
content:
remember, even if you weren't "accepted", the program is still open for anyone to participate. Accepted just means we will be providing funding and more hands on guidance for those people. 

We encourage anyone to learn in parallel, and apply for the next cohort when the time comes!

author: pipermerriam
content: Should be fleshed out in the next week or so.  Short answer is that every project is going to look different, but the general shape of the deliverables are going to be well organized written technical resources.

author: pipermerriam
content: You're looking at it.  the cohort-zero repository.  The reading links listed there.  More reading links in everyone's notes.  One of my hopes is that those of you participating will also be helping carve and easier path for the people who come through after you.

author: Deleted User
content: How can I do it in parallel, any suggestions?

author: Deleted User
content: should I try to be a third person to any of the 2 person teams?

author: pipermerriam
content:
The "teams" concept may get loosened.  I want people to explore what they are interested in, and cramming people into teams isn't going to be effective if there aren't natural pairs of people with similar interests.

If you want to do the program, simply start at the "stage 0" document in the cohort-zero repository and work your way forward.  Right now we're still largely in "stage 0" but over the next week or two I expect a few people to start in earnest into the "stage 1" part of exploring possible projects.  In fact, I know people have already started this because the `./notes` documents have started to get fleshed out to contain this type of thing.

author: Deleted User
content: gotcha, i saw the cohort zero repo and a couple of those projects looks really interesting

author: Deleted User
content: how do i find the people working on it and try my hand contributing?

author: pipermerriam
content:
write down what you figure out.  publish a development update with what you've learned.  read other people's dev updates.  follow along in the relevant channels in this server.  ask questions when you have good ones.  make a forum post.  read other people's forum posts.  open a pull request to the cohort-zero repository with your own notes.  participate.  learn.  write it all down again to see if you know it well enough to explain it to someone else.  publish that.  and so on....

If you want to start at the protocol level, there will be a lot of learning that comes before contributing.

author: defipunk
content:
I agree. Congrats to everyone. 

One related comment, however. I get that in this round, there were far too many applicants to evaluate technical merrit beyond just looking at githubs. However, I think you should reevaluate that for the next round, if you want to entice experienced developers that want to start contributing to open-source code. 

To use myself as an example, I have more than a decade (closer to 2, actually) of programming experience. However, 99% of it was closed-source, and mostly under NDA. Typically, large corporations like Google or Microsoft also have contracts that prevent real open-source contribution without jumping through hoops, as by default any of my ideas were owned by my employers.

author: defipunk
content: Btw. this is really just feedback. I wouldn't have taken myself either given the limited information üòâ

author: pipermerriam
content: I'm incredibly sympathetic to this.  Your situation sounds like exactly the type of thing that I'm still puzzling over.  People in positions like yours end up lacking some of the "strong signal" items despite being potentially very well qualified.  So the end result is that I probably have 15 applications that look almost the same as the "really good one" because resumes tend to be extremely low signal and mediocre candidates can look the same or better than the really good ones on a resume.  And I recognize that saying "just show up for free and contribute" is a very privileged thing and that not everyone can do that.  I just don't know how to tell "you" apart from the other 14 equally impressive resumes.

author: pipermerriam
content: (btw, I'm not actually talking directly about your application, just this concept in general)

author: defipunk
content:
Yep, 100%. I don't have a better idea other than interviews, and even those are relatively low signal. 
For me, this application has already been worth it because I wasn't aware of the portal network project beforehand, and that sounds like an ideal match for me. Although I haven't quite found my personal starting point, yet

author: pipermerriam
content: I would work to fund a well put together team to build a portal client that would be capable of being embedded in something like the MyCrypto desktop app.  Or research into how we can make the portal network accessible from a browser context (think if all 1 million metamask installs could all contribute just a little to support the network), this is currently not possible due to the network being UDP based, but maybe it can be bridged in someway using WebRTC between browsers....).  Or a team to add portal-network support to an existing client (ideally one that was actually interested in taking advantage of portal network functionality).

author: defipunk
content: I'm currently still catching up on your write-ups over the last months, but I'll follow-up üòâ
